section.name: PluginPoints : Annotations
section.p: DataNucleus is developed as a plugin-driven framework and one of the components that is pluggable is the reading of annotations. DataNucleus provides a support for JDO and JPA annotations, but is structured so that you can easily add your own annotations and have them usable within your DataNucleus usage.

DataNucleus supports Java annotations. More than this, it actually provides a pluggable framework whereby you can plug in your own annotations support. The JDO API plugin provides support for JDO annotations, and the JPA API plugin provides support for JPA annotations. You can extend DataNucleus's capabilities using the plugin extension org.datanucleus.annotations.

subsection.p:

subsection.name: Plugin Specification
subsection.p: So we now have our custom "annotation reader" and we just need to make this into a DataNucleus plugin. To do this you simply add a file plugin.xml to your JAR at the root. The file plugin.xml should look like this
subsection.source: <?xml version="1.0"?> <plugin id="mydomain.annotations" name="DataNucleus plug-ins" provider-name="My Company"> <extension point="org.datanucleus.annotations"> <annotations annotation-class="mydomain.annotations.MyAnnotationType" reader="mydomain.annotations.MyAnnotationReader"/> </extension> </plugin>
subsection.p: Note that you also require a MANIFEST.MF file as per the PluginPoints Guide.
So here we have our "annotations reader" class "MyAnnotationReader" which will process any classes annotated with the annotation "MyAnnotationType".
